awd_titl_txt: Energy Efficiency in Computing Logical Operations: Fundamental Limits with and Without Feedback
awd_abstract_narration:
The exponential increase in the ability to compute and store massive amount of data is fueling transformative changes in the human condition. It has led to a highly connected world with information being accessible at remote parts of the world. The current focus on interconnection of infrastructural systems such as the, power grid, financial markets, health care systems, and the Internet of Things (IoT), all bear a direct relationship to the advances in the integrated chips, where the complexity and the number of components has doubled almost every two years, following the Moore's law. Less known is the fact that the energy dissipation per computation has outpaced Moore's law which is at the heart of the mobile computation revolution, enabling, small form-factor devices packed with high computational capabilities that include, light laptops, tablets, and cell-phones. With such exponential increases, it is inevitable that limits of current approaches and practices for computation and memory related technologies are reached. This proposal addresses the basic operations of computation and memory with respect to the fundamental limits on the energy dissipation needed to perform the operations. It also studies the energy cost associated with measurement and feedback actions for performing computing and memory management operations. It provides proof of concept experiments and methods to demonstrate realizability of the computational and memory related operations with energetics tens of order smaller than the current practices. The associated analysis of fundamental primitives of computational operations and the proof of concept experiments will guide realizations of future energy efficient computational platforms and will continue the remarkable increase in speed and efficiencies with which computations are performed.


The focus of the project is on the fundamental limits on the energetics of computations and memory.  The project investigates primitives of computational operations both analytically and experimentally. It uses the abstraction of the state of a memory bit via the position of a particle in a double well potential in a thermal bath. Transfer of particle across the wells in a potential landscape is used to realize AND, NOT and erasure operations. Under the project goals, bounds on the minimum energetics of transferring the state of the particle in the double well potential will be analytically derived.  Here, key aspect of the approach is to estimate the change in entropy from the initial to the final state, and, relating the change in entropy to the energy associated with the transfer of state. The transfer of state can be accomplished with or without measuring the state of the particle in the double well potential; here, the effect of feedback where the measurement guides the protocol for transferring the state will be understood and analyzed. The theoretical foundations that link computations, statistical mechanics, and feedback will be accompanied by a versatile experimental platform. Double-well potentials will be realized by controlling optical fields which have the scale of energetics suited for the study. The experimental protocols will accommodate the need for different speeds of transferring the state; important to emulate quasi-static processes. Accurate and precise measurements of the position of the particle will be used for the estimation of the energy required in moving the particle across wells. The measurement protocols will be precisely characterized that will enable the study of closed-loop strategies that alter the transfer protocol based on measurements. The project will provide both analytics and proof-of-concept experimental realizations of basic primitives of computations with orders in magnitude smaller energy footprint.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Memory erasure related operations are ubiquitous in computing. Landauer's erasure principle states that any irreversible erasure protocol of a single bit memory needs work of at least kbTlog2, which translates to an extremely small amount and thus difficult to experimentally verify. Recent proof of concept experiments have demonstrated that the erasure protocols with work close to the Landauer limit can be devised. The scenario when measurments of the memory state are fed back to the  erasure protocol apparently beats the Landauer's limit. Here, under feedback, where the state of the bit can be measured, the work needed for a bit erasure can be lower than kbTlog2. We analyzed the energetics of feedback enabled erasure, while incorporating the imperfections of experimentally realized memory and bit erasure protocols that admit failure probabilities. We delineated the role of uncertainty in measurements and its effects on the work and entropy changes for a feedback-based erasure. We quantitatively demonstrated that the deficit between the Landauer limit and the minimum average work needed in a feedback-based erasure is accounted for by the mutual information between the measurement and the state of a memory, while incorporating the imperfections inherent in any realization. We experimentally demonstrated analysis results on a memory and erasure protocol realized using optical fields. 

Thus this project studied the energetics of feedback based erasure or Closed-loop erasure. It has delineated the energetics of  the interplay between thermodynamic and informational entropy.

Toward delineating the outcomes of the project we provide the following description. Figure 1(a) shows a Brownian particle in a bistable potential well which  is considered as an abstract memory model. Experimentally, a bistable potential well is realized by alternately focusing a trapping laser at two trap locations using time multiplexing enabled by an Acousto Optical Deflector. The time spent by the laser at a trap location is much smaller than the time constant of the particle, which helps in creating a bistable potential well. Duty ratio, d, is defined as the fraction of the total time spent by the laser at left location. Duty ratio provides a control on the asymmetry of the bistable potential, where d not equal to half results in asymmetric wells.

Figure 1(b) shows the system of interest which consists of a Brownian particle and a measurement device, rest is considered as surrounding. The erasure protocol involves three steps:  (i) Measurement of the state of memory (ii) feedback action where the potential is altered to move the bit to the reset state if the measurement indicates that the state is not in the zero state (iii) the memory state is reset.

The closed-loop erasure protocol is implemented for various values of duty ratio's; the external work done during the feedback is computed as a function of duty ratio, as shown in Figure 2. In quasistatic limit (duty ratio approaching 0.5), the average feedback work is calculated to be less than the Landauer limit kbTlog2 by a difference of 0.560kbT, which is the energy deficit in the closed-loop protocol and in agreement with the mutual information calculated purely from quantities during measurement (≈ 0.6kbT). The distribution of work is shown in Figure 3. Figure 3 contains a probability distribution with a left and a right lobe for a given duty ratio. Left lobe corresponds to scenario where the potential wells are not tilted because the sensor measured the particle to be in left well. The lobe present on the right side of the spike contributes significantly to average feedback work. The right lobe represents the work done in tilting the potentials when a particle is initialized in the right well.

Key Outcomes

The key outcomes include:

  • Energetics of feedback enabled erasure is quantified, while incorporating the imperfections of experimentally realized memory and bit erasure protocols that admit failure probabilities.
  • Interplay between measurement noise, erasure performance and external work is analyzed.
  • Quantitatively demonstrated that the deficit between the Landauer limit and the minimum average work needed in a feedback-based erasure is accounted for by the mutual information between the measurement and the state of a memory, while incorporating the imperfections inherent in any realization.
  • Experimentally validated analysis based results on a memory and erasure protocol realized using optical fields.
  • Obtained sharp bounds on the concavity deficit of a mixture distribution with the results instantiated to physics of bistable potentials in relation to the erasure process. Here, the difference between the entropy of a simplex of pdfs and the same simplex of entropies of the pdfs was obtained. These results hold considerable significance beyond the specific focus of the project on erasure.
  • Under broader impacts the project has led to graudate student traning, new course on the energetics at the small scale and the knowledge dissemination of the new understanding of the energetcis at the small scale.
